summary: This is a transcript of a DOJ Office of the Inspector General interview with a New York City medical examiner who performed the autopsy on Jeffrey Epstein. The examiner details the autopsy findings, explains why the evidence points to suicide by hanging, and discusses questions about the ligature and scene investigation.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The subject of the autopsy and investigation. The medical examiner determined his cause of death was hanging and manner of death was suicide.

persons.name: Dr. [Redacted]
persons.context: The witness being interviewed. She performed the autopsy on Jeffrey Epstein on August 11, 2019, and explains her findings and conclusions in detail.

Brothers. Mark Epstein hired a private medical examiner to observe his brother's autopsy.
Mark Epstein hired Dr. [Redacted] as a private medical examiner to be present at his brother's autopsy.

events.title: Autopsy of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Dr. [Redacted] performs the autopsy on Jeffrey Epstein at the New York City Office of the Chief Medical Examiner.

events.title: Previous suicide attempt by Epstein
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found with a noose around his neck in an apparent suicide attempt while in custody.

events.title: Epstein's death and expected autopsy
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein is found dead in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center. The medical examiner's office is notified and expects to receive the body.

events.title: OIG Interview with Medical Examiner
events.description: DOJ Office of the Inspector General conducts a recorded interview with the medical examiner who performed Epstein's autopsy.

locations: New York City Office of the Chief Medical Examiner
Dane County Medical Examiner's Office, Madison, Wisconsin
keyFacts: The medical examiner found the autopsy findings 'very, very consistent with a suicidal hanging,' citing a ligature furrow, petechial hemorrhages, plethora, and specific fracture patterns of the hyoid bone and thyroid cartilage.
The examiner noted a lack of defensive wounds, struggle marks, or other trauma on Epstein's body, which would be expected in a homicide by strangulation.
There was confusion and lack of certainty about which item from the cell was the actual ligature used in the hanging, with the examiner expressing doubt about the item presented to her.
Toxicology tests detected no substances in Epstein's system at the time of death.
The examiner stated that no one attempted to coerce or bribe her into ruling the death a suicide, though she received unpleasant calls from Epstein's family who were unhappy with the determination.
